citeinfo.title: DISPERSAL HAZARDS OF PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS BY BATS ND HUMAN ACTIVITY AT HIBERNACULA IN SUMMER

descript.abstract: Bats occupying hibernacula during summer months may play an important role in the epidemiology of white-nose syndrome (WNS). For example, bats exposed to viable Pseudogymnoascus destructans (Pd), the causative agent of WNS, in late summer could spread the fungus by transmitting it to other bats or to other locations suitable for establishment of new environmental reservoirs. To explore risks for transmission of Pd during the non-hibernal season, we screened bats using hibernacula between July 18 to August 22, 2012 and associated environmental samples for presence of Pd. Study sites within the eastern United States included six hibernacula known to harbor Pd and two hibernacula in which bats with WNS had not been previously observed. Standard demographic and morphometric data were recorded for bats captured from inside each study site. Sample types evaluated for the presence of Pd included bat wing swabs, guano pellets from individual bats, swabs of hibernaculum walls, and sediments from the hibernaculum floor. Additionally, swabs of various trapping and processing equipment and clothing worn into study sites were evaluated for the presence of Pd.
descript.purpose: Documents bat species diversity during summer months at select hibernacula; assesses the prevalence of Pd exposure in bats that use contaminated environmental reservoirs (hibernacula) during the summer; identifies which sample types from bats and in the environment should be used for reliable Pd surveillance in summer months; demonstrates potential for contamination of equipment/clothing by Pd when working at or within Pd-contaminated environments even when there is no clinical signs of disease in the bat population
descript.supplinf: The bat population at each hibernaculum was classified as either stable or reduced based on Winter 2012/2013 population estimates divided by the average of two to five years of available pre-WNS winter census data (including data from the first year of WNS detection). Hibernacula with >25% decline in winter count estimates since the detection of WNS were considered to have reduced populations due to WNS.

taxonsys.taxoncom: relied on local bat biologists for species identification by visual inspection

taxonomy.taxongen: several bat species were used in this investigation

idinfo.accconst: Yes, several study sites contain T and E bat species so site names have been masked and only county-level spatial resolution is provided
idinfo.useconst: Yes, several study sites contain T and E bat species so site names have been masked and only county-level spatial resolution is provided

tool.tooldesc: statistical tool to evaluate site charateristics

attracc.attraccr: visual inspection of data from handwritten datasheets at time of data entry into MS Access database; retained original hand-written datasheets as reference; ensured digital scale and digital calipers were set to proper units and zeroed prior to each new measurement; calculated certain datafields in MSExcel from original raw data (BMI)

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: excluded demographic and morphometric data of bats captured on outside of site entrances; recorded species and noted if it was a recapture

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: Both lab and field work were done to create these data

citeinfo.origin: BRUNET-ROSSINNI, A. K. AND G. S. WILKINSON
citeinfo.title: Methods for age estimation and senescence in bats. In Ecological and behavioral methods for the study of bats

procstep.procdesc: Field data (species, sex, age-class, repro status, body wt, R forearm length, UV status, WDI) and samples collected between July 18-August 22, 2012. Samples (wing swabs, guano, environmental swabs, sediment, gear swabs) stored frozen at -20C for up to 6 weeks before transferring to -80C. Samples processed between May 2013-May 2014.

We evaluated the effects of site characteristics (i.e., hibernacula with stable winter bat populations and hibernacula with reduced winter bat populations) and sample type (sediment versus wall swab) on observed PCR results using linear regression in a Bayesian framework with R2OpenBUGS (Sturtz et al., 2005) in R (R Core Team, 2013). We modeled observed PCR Ct values (y) for each individual i as normally distributed with a mean of Œº and variance of œÑ (i.e. yi ~ ∆ù(Œº,œÑ)).

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
